dialogues.speaker: NIGHT. EXT. SIDE OF KELLER HOUSE.
dialogues.text: KELLER standing lamp in hand watching the doctor's buggy recede in the night. Suddenly from the house behind him comes a knifing scream. KELLER wheels, the scream comes again and the CAMERA follows KELLER's run with the lamp across the yard. 3. NIGHT. INT. KELLER HOUSE. KELLER runs into the house and up the dark stairs. 4. NIGHT. INT. HELEN'S NURSERY. KELLER bursts into the bedroom where KATE is screaming at the crib, her look intent on the baby and terrible.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Katie, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 c o.w- u UED She makes a pass with her hand in the crib, at the baby's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: KATE (Cont'd) She can't see. Look at her eyes. She takes the lamp from him, moves it before the child's face. She can't seel

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: (HOARSELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or hear. When I screamed she didn't blink. Not an eyelash --

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Helen. Heleni

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: She can't hear youl

dialogues.speaker: HELENL
dialogues.text: His face has something like fury in it, crying the child' name; KATE almost fainting presses her knuckles to her mouth, to stop her own cry.

dialogues.speaker: DAY. INT. KELLEL HOUSE
dialogues.text: The stairs in the Keller House. In the foreground we see the bannisters, in the background the wall. A shadow.of the erratic, staggering figure of 5 year old HELEN appear on the wall, moving slowly. The two Negro children scamper past -- their excited laughter coming to us, in contrast to the mute HELEN. In CU, in the FG, HELEN'S little hands come into the frame, grasping the bannister rail. 6. DAY. EXT. YARD - TITLE SHOT. HIGH LONG SHOT lookinвЂ™, down on lines of bed sheets hun up in the Keller yard to dry. It appears to be a kind of (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: maze, the sheets blowing in the wind; and staggering amon them is the figure of the child, HELEN 5 years old, reach ing out, struggling, buffeted by the damp, blowing sheets CRANE DOWN towards the figure. HELEN lashes out, her face frightened, unknowing --- she pulls down a sheet, be comes tangled in its folds, almost hysterical. In the BG  KATE comes rushing from the house -- to help her. 7. NIGHT. INT. LIVING ROOM KELLER HOUSE - TITLE SHOT. There is a Christmas tree with decorations and in a WIDE SHOT we see HELEN, 7 years old, reaching up into tree. At a window we see the faces of Percy 8 years, and Martha 7 years, looking in. HELENrS hand gets a Christmas ball and rips it down, shattering at her feet. CRAB IN AND AROUND coming to the side of the tree, seeing HELENtS hands, another ball, she pulls it down. We see her face, blurred out, through the pine branches and needles, and beyond her the other children watching. $. DAY. EXT. AFIELD - TITLE SHOT. A WIDE HIGH SHOT. We see the lonely expanse of field with 0 a low grass sprouting up, in the BG is the Keller house perhaps. Going slowly across the field is the figure of the child HELEN, Patty Duke. From in under CAMERA comes KATE, following her. (CONTINUE SCRIPT)

dialogues.speaker: DAY. EXT. BACKYARD KELLER HOUSE AND PUMP
dialogues.text: Scene will be out MOS up until RINGING OF BELL: Now we are in leaf-dappled sunlight in the Keller yard, o three kneeling children and an old dog around the pump. V INEY with jug on way to barn to get milk. The dog is a setter named BELLE, and she is sleeping. Two of the children are Negroes, MARTHA and PERCY. The third child is HELEN, quite unkempt, in body a vivacious little person with a fine head, attractive, but noticeably blind one eye larger and protruding; her gestures are abrupt, insistent, lacking in human restraint, and her face never 0 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: smiles. She is flanked by the other two, in a litter of 0 paper-doll cutouts, and while they speak, HELEN'S hands thrust at their faces in turn, feeling baffledly at the movements of their lips. The CAMERA is on this; the dialogue is only background.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (SNIPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Itm gonna cut off this doe- torts leg, one, two, now then --

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: Why you cuttin' off that doctor's legs?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna give him a operation. Now I'm gonna cut off his arms, one, two. Now I'm gonna fix up She pushes HELEN'S hand away from her mouth. You stop that.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: Cut off his stomach, that's a good operation. 0

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, I'm gonna cut off his head first, he got a bad cold.

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna be much of that doc- tor left to fix up, time you finish all them opera-- But HELEN is poking her fingers inside his mouth, to feel his tongue; he bites at them, annoyed, and she jerks them away. HELEN now fingers her own lips, moving them in imitation, but soundlessly. Again the CAMERA on this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: What you do, bite hand?

dialogues.speaker: PERCY
dialogues.text: That's how I do, she keep pokint. her fingers in my mouth, I just bite 'em off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.That she tryin' do now? 0

dialogues.speaker: PEERCY
dialogues.text: She tryint talk. She gonna get read. Looka her try in' talk.. ILLEN is scowling, the lips under her fingertips moving in silence, growing more and more frantic, until in a bizarre rage she bites at her own fingers. This sends PERCY off into laughter, but alarms :MARTHA.

dialogues.speaker: MARTI
dialogues.text: Hey, you stop now. She pulls EELEI' S hand down, You just sit quiet and But at once HELEIT topples LTARTHA on her back, knees pinning her shoulders down, and ;-ravs the sissors. MARTHA screams, hile her tied b _nchlets of hair ВЈ17 off in snips of the scissors. PERCY darts to the bell stria on the porch, yanks it W THE DELL RIPGS. bOA. DAY. INT. LIVID ROOLI

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN X LLER is at work at his deal. JA ES is at his ease in conversation with KATE and AUNT EV. KATE is serving a cool refreshment. ITAR RINGING OF BELL. KATE rushes out the door followed more slowly by A"MITT W, leaving behind JAILS & FELLER. 11. KATE 0? ?* NINC DOOR ONTO ARCH SEES THE SCONE. Five years have done much to her, the girlish play- fulness is gone, she is a woman settled in grief.

dialogues.speaker: BATE
dialogues.text: (for the thousandth time) Helen. She is dorm the steps at once to them, seizing Ii LE'TT S wrists and lifting her off IARTHA. VINE= runs in and chases MARTHA and PERCY OFF. 0 6A.

There is a cradle with a sleeping infant, T1lIrDRED: c".PT_":IN KE!,L:_R in spectacles is working over netrs- paper pages at a corner desk; a benign AMIT EV, wearing a hat, with a sew in-,. basket on a sofa is put- tin the finishing stitches on a big shapeless doll made out of towels; an ineol ont young man of I"TE' S are, JA S 1lc_ tR turns from the window to look at HE L_,'N. i LE halts, her hands alert to grope, and E KATE turns her to the AUNT, who gives her the doll, the AUNT is meanwhile speaking to TELLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, something ought to be done for that child.

dialogues.speaker: T-
dialogues.text: A refresh,; ng suggg;estion. 'AВ°l .at?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: '-Thy, this ver-T famous Perkins School in Poston; they're just supposed to do wonders. ICc'ELLER The child's been to speci lists everywhere. dialogues.text: :ratie, Howe many tines can you let- then brew.{ your heart? Any number of tines, h T e foreroinz and follovrin" dialo,ue is peripheral to the we are on }EL ' T 1 She sits on the or to explore the doll t71lth h.r fingers, gravely, and her hand pauses over the face: this is no face, a blan area, and it troubles her. CLOS'_' UP on her finger-- tips searching for flaatures. She tans ouestioninSly f'o:' eyes, but no one notices. She then yanks at her _Jfl''T1S dress, and taps amain viForousRy for eyes. Oc oO:T'! I Ico n 0

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: What, child? Obviously not hearing, HELEN commences to go around from person to person, tapping her eyes, but no one attends or understands.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (No break) As long as there's the least chance. For her to see. Or hear, or --

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: There isntt. Now I must finish here.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I think, with your permission, Captain, I'd like to write to the Perkins School.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: I said no, Katie.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: Why, writing does no harm, Arthur, only a little bitty letter. To see if they can help her.

dialogues.speaker: FELLER
dialogues.text: They can't.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We won't know that; to be a fact, Captain, until afLLer you write. 13. HELEN NOW IS GROPING AMONG THING.' ON FELL ER t S DES PAWS HIS PAPERS TO THE FLOOR. KJ MLIM IS EXASPERATED.

dialogues.speaker: K I J,ER
dialogues.text: Katie. KATE quickly turns HELEN away, and retrives the papers. I might as well tAВ°y to work ina henyard as in th.s house -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (PLACATING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really ought to put her away Father.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (Staring up) What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Some asylum. It's the kindest thing.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: Why, she's your sister, James, not a nobody --

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Half sister, and half-mentally defective, she can't even keep herself clean. It's not pleasant to see her about all the time.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Do you dare? Complain of what 0 you can see?

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: (Very annoyed) This discussion is at an end] HELEN gropes her way with the doll back to AUNT EV. The house is at sixes and sevens  from morning 'til night over the childl I want some peace here, I don't care how, but one way we won't have it is by rushing up and down the country every time someone hears of a new quack. I'm as sensible to this affliction as --

dialogues.speaker: HELEN WITH AUNT EV
dialogues.text: fingering her dress, yanks two buttons from it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: Helena My buttons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HELEN pushes the buttons into the doll's face. KATE 0 now sees, comes swiftly to kneel, lifts HELEN'S hand to her own eyes in question.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Eyes? HELEN nods energetically. She wants the doll to have eyes. Another kind of silence now, while KATE takes pins and buttons from the sewing basket and attaches them to the doll as eyes. KELLER stands, caught, and watches morosely, AUNT EV blinks and conceals her emotion by inspecting her dress.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: My goodness me, I'm not decent.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: She doesn't know better, Aunt Ev. I'll sew them on again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 It's worth a couple of buttons, Kate, look. HELEN now has the doll with eyes, and cannot contain herself for joy; she rocks the doll, pats it vigorously, kisses it. This child has more sense than all these men Kellers, if there's ever any way to reach that mind of hers.

dialogues.speaker: HESITATINGLY OVERTURNS IT.
dialogues.text: The swaddled baby tumbles out and CAPTAIN KELLER barely manages to dive and catch it in time.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Helen! All are in commotion, the baby screams, but HELEN un- perturbed is lying her doll in its place, KATE on her (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: knees, pulls her hands off the cradle, wringing them; 0 HELEN is bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Helen, Helen, you're not to do such things, how can I make you

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: (Hoarsely, handing the baby to AUNT EV) Katie.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: How can I get it into your head, my darling, my poor --

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Katie, some way of teaching her an iota of discipline has to be

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (FLARING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you discipline an afflicted child? Is it her fault? 0 HELEN'S fingers have fluttered to her Mother's lips, vainly trying to comprehend their movements; we are close on these two.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: I didn't say it was her fault.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Then whose? I don't know what to dot How can I teach her, beat her -- until she's black and blue?

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: It's not safe to let her run around loose. Now there must be a way of confining her, somehow, so she can't---

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where, in a cage? She's a growing child, she has to use her limbs!

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Answer me one thing, is it fair to Mildred here? (CONTINUIM)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (INEXORABLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you willing to put her away? Now HELEN'S face darkens in the same rage as at herself earlier, and her hand strikes at KATE'S lips. KATE catches her again, and HELEN begins to kick, struggle, twist.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: She wants to talk, like -- be like you and me. She holds HELEN struggling until we HEAR from the child her first sound so far, an inarticulate weird noise in her throat such as an animal in a trap might make; and KATE releases her. The second she is free, HELEN blunders away collides violently with a chair, falls, and sits weeping. KATE comes to her, embraces, caresses soothes her, and buries her own face in her hair, until she can control her voice.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Every day she slips further away. I don't know how to call her back.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EV
dialogues.text: Oh, I've a mind to write to Boston myself. If that School can't help her, maybe they'll know somebody who can.

dialogues.speaker: KELLER
dialogues.text: (Presently, heavily) I'll write to Perkins, Katie. He stands with the baby in his clasp, staring at HELEN'S head, hanging down on KATE'S arm.

dialogues.speaker: OF TRAIN.
dialogues.text: M.R. ANAGNOS on platform with ANNIE'S suitcase, is reach- ing up to help ANNIE mount steps. CAMERA is behind ANNIE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: 0 -- only that a suitable governess has been found here and will come. It will no doubt be difficult for you there, Annie, but it has been difficult for you at our school too hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: ...В°This is my last time to counsel you, Annie, and you do lack some -- by some I mean all -- what, tact, or talent to bencT. To others. And what has saved you on one or more occasions at Perkins is that there was nowhere to expel you to. Above ANNIEIS seat ANAGNOS puts her suitcase, looking -down at her. Your eyes hurt? 0 18. CU ANNIE - WEARING SMOKED GLASSES.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: My ears, Mr. Anagnos.

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: (SEVERELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere but back to that dreadful place where children learn to be saucy. Annie, I know how unhappy it was there, but that battle is dead and done with. Why not let it stay buried?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (CHEERILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think God must owe me a resur- rection.

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: (A bit shocked) What? 14 19. ANNIE TAPS HER BROW.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: 0 Well, he keeps digging up that battle.

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: That is not a proper thing to say. Annie, be humble. He extends a gift to her.. You'll need their affection, work- ing with this child. ANNIE, not quite comprehending, looks at gift. A gift with our affection. ANNIE opens a small box and sees a garnet ring. She looks up, blinking, then down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Dear Mr. Anagnos, (Her voice is trembling)

dialogues.speaker: I--
dialogues.text: But she swallows over getting the ring on her finger and cannot continue until she finds a woebegone joke. 0 Well, what should I say -- I'm an ignorant, opinionated girl and everything I am I owe to you?

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is only half true, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which half? The train lurches. ANAGNOS bends and kisses her on the cheek and says,

dialogues.speaker: ANAGNOS
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (She calls after him

dialogues.speaker: LOUDLY
dialogues.text: I won't give them any trouble. I'll be so ladylike they won't notice I've come. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 0 Passengers behind ANNIE turn reacting to her shout. She is conscious of this and sinks down'in seat. Past ANNIE, through window of train, we see ANAGNOS join 5 or 6 blind girls on the platform, and the train departs. BEGIN MONTAGE SEQUENCES OF TRAIN SHOTS. 20. ANNIE, TRAVELING, SITTING IN SEAT OF MOVING TRAIN. 21. SCENE IN FILTHY TRAIN, ANNIE READING PERKINS REPORT. SEAT DIFFERENT INDICATING ANOTHER TRAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly train rushes into a tunnel, and darkness comes  over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Where are we going, Annie?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANNIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANNIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: I said I'm taking care of you.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Where we go...

dialogues.speaker: STYLIZED TEWKESBURY ADMISSIONS OFFICE.
dialogues.text: YOUNG JIMMIE and YOUNG ANNIE are standing in front of desk. We do not see man sitting behind desk, but we hear his voice.

dialogues.speaker: 11A13' S VOICE
dialogues.text: Annie Sullivan, aged nine, virtually 0 blind; Jaynes Sullivan, aged seven, -- what's the matter with your legs sonny?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: It's his hip, N ster, he was born that way. is AN' SВ§ VOICE Can't he walk without that crutch? The GIRL shakes her head.
